gold_answer: A Payment Service User that is not a Natural Person and a Payment Service Provider may mutually agree in writing to exclude the application of Rule 19.2.16, which pertains to charges for information [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297]. However, if Rule 19.2.16 is applied, any charges imposed must not exceed the actual costs incurred by the Payment Service Provider in providing the information [#TGT:0ddfb32a-c23e-4da9-af5e-d04b51f92c41].
rag_answer: A Payment Service User and a Payment Service Provider may agree in writing to exclude the application of Rule 19.2.16 when the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person. This agreement allows them to bypass the rule concerning charges for information, which would otherwise require the Payment Service Provider to disclose any charges related to the provision or availability of information under the Framework Contract [#P:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297]. If Rule 19.2.16 is applied, the Payment Service Provider must provide details of all charges payable by the Payment Service User, including a breakdown of the amounts of all charges, ensuring transparency in the financial obligations of the Payment Service User [#P:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b]. This agreement to exclude the rule must be documented in writing, ensuring both parties are aware and have consented to the exclusion of this requirement.

question: When can a Payment Service User and Provider decide not to follow Rule 19.2.16, and what is the rule about charges if they do follow it?
gold_answer: A Payment Service User that is not a Natural Person and a Payment Service Provider can agree in writing not to follow Rule 19.2.16, which deals with charges for information [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297]. If they do follow Rule 19.2.16, the charges must not be more than the actual costs the Provider has for giving the information [#TGT:0ddfb32a-c23e-4da9-af5e-d04b51f92c41].
rag_answer: A Payment Service User and Provider can decide not to follow Rule 19.2.16 if the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person and both parties agree in writing to exclude this rule. Rule 19.2.16 pertains to the charges for information provided by the Payment Service Provider to the Payment Service User. If they choose to follow Rule 19.2.16, the Framework Contract must include details of all charges payable by the Payment Service User to the Payment Service Provider, including those connected to information which is provided or made available, and where applicable, a breakdown of the amounts of all charges. This ensures transparency in the financial obligations of the Payment Service User concerning the information provided by the Payment Service Provider. [#P:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] [#P:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b]

question: When a Payment Service Provider intends to make unilateral changes to a Framework Contract, what are the notification requirements and rights of the Payment Service User under the relevant rules?
gold_answer: When a Payment Service Provider plans to unilaterally amend a Framework Contract, they must inform the Payment Service User of the proposed changes at least two months before these changes take effect [#TGT:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5]. Additionally, the Payment Service Provider must notify the Payment Service User that they will be deemed to have accepted the changes unless they object before the proposed date of entry into force [#SRC:3f0b9767-ce03-4986-bf5f-630548e2a5e1]. The Payment Service User also retains the right to terminate the Framework Contract without charge at any time before the changes take effect [#SRC:3f0b9767-ce03-4986-bf5f-630548e2a5e1].
rag_answer: When a Payment Service Provider intends to make unilateral changes to a Framework Contract, they must adhere to specific notification requirements and respect the rights of the Payment Service User. The Payment Service Provider is required to inform the Payment Service User that they will be deemed to have accepted the proposed changes unless they notify the provider to the contrary before the changes take effect [#P:3f0b9767-ce03-4986-bf5f-630548e2a5e1]. Additionally, the Payment Service User must be informed of their right to terminate the Framework Contract without charge at any time before the proposed changes come into force [#P:3f0b9767-ce03-4986-bf5f-630548e2a5e1]. The Framework Contract should also include terms under which the Payment Service User will be deemed to have accepted changes unless they notify the provider otherwise before the changes take effect [#P:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b]. These requirements ensure that the Payment Service User is adequately informed and has the opportunity to respond to or reject changes, maintaining a fair and transparent contractual relationship.

question: If a Payment Service Provider wants to change the terms of a Framework Contract, what must they tell the Payment Service User, and when?
gold_answer: The Payment Service Provider must inform the Payment Service User about any changes to the Framework Contract terms at least two months before these changes are set to start [#TGT:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5]. They must also tell the Payment Service User that they will be considered to have accepted the changes unless they say otherwise before the changes begin [#SRC:3f0b9767-ce03-4986-bf5f-630548e2a5e1]. Furthermore, the Payment Service User can end the Framework Contract without any fees before the changes take effect [#SRC:3f0b9767-ce03-4986-bf5f-630548e2a5e1].
rag_answer: If a Payment Service Provider wishes to change the terms of a Framework Contract, they must inform the Payment Service User of the proposed changes and the implications of not responding. Specifically, the Payment Service Provider must notify the Payment Service User that they will be deemed to have accepted the changes if they do not object before the proposed date of entry into force. Additionally, the Payment Service User must be informed of their right to terminate the Framework Contract without charge at any time before the changes take effect. This ensures that the Payment Service User is fully aware of their rights and the consequences of inaction regarding the proposed changes. The notification must be communicated in accordance with Rule 19.2.4, which outlines the manner and frequency of providing information under the Framework Contract. This process is crucial to maintain transparency and protect the interests of the Payment Service User in the event of unilateral changes by the Payment Service Provider. [#P:3f0b9767-ce03-4986-bf5f-630548e2a5e1] [#P:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b]

question: How must a Payment Service Provider implement changes to the exchange rate used in Payment Transactions, and what is the required notice period for changes to the Framework Contract terms?
gold_answer: A Payment Service Provider must implement changes to the exchange rate used in Payment Transactions in a neutral manner, ensuring that the changes do not collectively discriminate against Payment Service Users [#TGT:e696d18d-c269-44cd-907e-9701efbb42dc]. Additionally, any proposed changes to the existing terms of the Framework Contract must be communicated to the Payment Service User no later than two months before they are to take effect [#SRC:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5].
rag_answer: A Payment Service Provider must implement changes to the exchange rate used in Payment Transactions in a neutral manner that does not collectively discriminate against Payment Service Users [#P:e696d18d-c269-44cd-907e-9701efbb42dc]. Changes in exchange rates may be applied immediately and without notice if such a right is agreed under the Framework Contract and the changes are based on the Reference Exchange Rate information provided to the Payment Service User, or if the changes are more favorable to the Payment Service User [#P:d1ff305e-8ed4-430f-a3ca-684f0dc00939]. Regarding changes to the terms of the Framework Contract, the proposed terms under which the Payment Service User will be deemed to have accepted changes must be clearly stated, unless the Payment Service User notifies the Payment Service Provider that they do not accept such changes before the proposed date of their entry into force [#P:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b]. This ensures that the Payment Service User is adequately informed and has the opportunity to reject any unfavorable changes before they take effect.

question: When a Payment Service Provider changes the exchange rate for transactions, how should it be done, and how much notice is needed for changing contract terms?
gold_answer: When changing the exchange rate for transactions, a Payment Service Provider must ensure the change is neutral and does not unfairly affect Payment Service Users [#TGT:e696d18d-c269-44cd-907e-9701efbb42dc]. For changes to contract terms, the provider must give the Payment Service User at least two months' notice before the changes take effect [#SRC:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5].
rag_answer: When a Payment Service Provider changes the exchange rate for transactions, it can apply these changes immediately and without notice if such a right is agreed upon in the Framework Contract and the changes are based on the Reference Exchange Rate information provided to the Payment Service User, or if the changes are more favorable to the Payment Service User [#P:d1ff305e-8ed4-430f-a3ca-684f0dc00939]. For changes in contract terms, the Framework Contract must specify the proposed terms under which the Payment Service User will be deemed to have accepted changes unless they notify the Payment Service Provider that they do not accept such changes before the proposed date of their entry into force [#P:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b]. This ensures that the Payment Service User is informed and has the opportunity to reject changes before they take effect. It is crucial for the Payment Service Provider to clearly communicate these terms and any changes to maintain transparency and compliance with the regulatory framework.

question: Under what conditions may the parties agree to exclude the application of Rule 19.11.1(3) and Rule 19.20.1(4) concerning a Low Value Payment Instrument, and how does this relate to the Payer's liability for unauthorised Payment Transactions?
gold_answer: The parties may agree to exclude the application of Rule 19.11.1(3) and Rule 19.20.1(4) when a Low Value Payment Instrument does not allow for the stopping or prevention of its use [#SRC:1db4fdad-1fa0-4aae-ad68-56d8705902d9]. This agreement is relevant to the Payer's liability for unauthorised Payment Transactions, as the Payer is generally not liable for losses incurred after notifying the Payment Service Provider of the loss, theft, or unauthorised use of the Payment Instrument, provided that the notification means were available as per Rule 19.11.1(3) [#TGT:bc276114-5360-4893-a879-9539f81273ce]. Therefore, if the parties agree to exclude these rules, the Payer may still be liable for certain losses unless other conditions, such as the Payment Service Provider's failure to apply Strong Customer Authentication, are met [#TGT:bc276114-5360-4893-a879-9539f81273ce].
rag_answer: The parties may agree to exclude the application of Rule 19.11.1(3) and Rule 19.20.1(4) concerning a Low Value Payment Instrument under specific conditions. This is permissible when the Low Value Payment Instrument does not allow for the stopping or prevention of its use. In such cases, the requirement for notification of the loss of the Payment Instrument (Rule 19.11.1(3)) and the provision that the Payer is not liable for certain losses (Rule 19.20.1(4)) do not apply [#P:1db4fdad-1fa0-4aae-ad68-56d8705902d9]. This arrangement directly impacts the Payer's liability for unauthorised Payment Transactions, as the usual protections and obligations related to notification and liability may be waived by mutual agreement of the parties involved. It is important to note that this exclusion is contingent upon the specific functionality of the Low Value Payment Instrument, particularly its inability to be stopped or prevented from use, which must be acknowledged and agreed upon by both parties [#P:1db4fdad-1fa0-4aae-ad68-56d8705902d9].

question: When can the rules about telling the Payment Service Provider about a lost Payment Instrument not apply, and how does this affect who pays for unauthorised transactions?
gold_answer: The rules about notifying the Payment Service Provider of a lost Payment Instrument may not apply if the Payment Instrument is a Low Value Payment Instrument that cannot be stopped or prevented from being used [#SRC:1db4fdad-1fa0-4aae-ad68-56d8705902d9]. This affects who pays for unauthorised transactions because, normally, the Payer is not responsible for losses after they notify the Payment Service Provider, as long as the means to notify were available [#TGT:bc276114-5360-4893-a879-9539f81273ce]. If these rules do not apply, the Payer might still have to cover some losses unless other conditions, like the Payment Service Provider not using Strong Customer Authentication, are met [#TGT:bc276114-5360-4893-a879-9539f81273ce].
rag_answer: The rules regarding notifying the Payment Service Provider about a lost Payment Instrument do not apply when a Low Value Payment Instrument is used anonymously or when the Payment Service Provider cannot prove that a Payment Transaction was authorised due to reasons related to the Low Value Payment Instrument. In such cases, the liability rules for unauthorised Payment Transactions are also not applicable. Specifically, the Payment Service Provider's liability for unauthorised transactions and the Payer's or Payee's liability for such transactions do not apply, which means that the usual requirement for the Payer to be liable up to a maximum of US$50 for losses incurred from unauthorised transactions does not hold. This exemption is significant because it alters the standard liability framework, potentially leaving the Payment Service Provider unable to claim the US$50 from the Payer for unauthorised transactions under these specific circumstances. [#P:17855732-f49e-4440-a80e-aea492213f9a] [#P:1afab0bc-e878-4699-ae0f-60b469cb4c45]

question: Under what circumstances can a Payment Service User and a Payment Service Provider agree to modify the liability rules for charges and interest related to non-execution or defective execution of Payment Transactions?
gold_answer: A Payment Service User that is not a Natural Person and a Payment Service Provider may agree in writing to modify certain rules, including those related to liability for charges and interest due to non-execution or defective execution of Payment Transactions. Specifically, they may agree that Rule 19.21.5, which concerns liability for charges, does not apply [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297]. Additionally, the Payment Service Provider is generally liable for any charges and interest the Payment Service User incurs due to non-execution, defective, or late execution of a Payment Transaction [#TGT:7a0dd0a5-6eb8-41ba-8900-b4048ce180fa].
rag_answer: A Payment Service User and a Payment Service Provider can agree to modify the liability rules for charges and interest related to the non-execution or defective execution of Payment Transactions under specific circumstances. This agreement is permissible when the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, allowing both parties to agree in writing that certain rules, including Rule 19.21.5, do not apply. Rule 19.21.5 specifically addresses the liability of a Payment Service Provider for any charges and interest that the Payment Service User must pay due to non-execution, defective, or late execution of a Payment Transaction. The parties may also agree on a different time period concerning unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions for the purposes of Rule 19.17.1. This flexibility is contingent upon the mutual written agreement between the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider, thereby allowing them to tailor the liability framework to their specific needs and circumstances. Such agreements must be documented in writing to ensure clarity and enforceability. [#P:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] [#P:7a0dd0a5-6eb8-41ba-8900-b4048ce180fa]

question: When can a Payment Service User and Provider decide not to follow the usual rules about charges and interest for payment problems?
gold_answer: If the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, they can agree in writing with the Payment Service Provider to ignore some rules, including those about charges for payment issues [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297]. Normally, the Payment Service Provider has to cover any charges and interest the User faces because of payment problems [#TGT:7a0dd0a5-6eb8-41ba-8900-b4048ce180fa].
rag_answer: A Payment Service User and Provider can decide not to follow the usual rules about charges and interest for payment problems when they are dealing with Low-Value Payment Instruments under a Framework Contract. In such cases, the Payment Service Provider is not required to disclose general information concerning the Payment Service Provider and the relevant Payment Service as per Section 19.2. Instead, they must provide the Payer with information about the main characteristics of the Payment Service, including the way the Payment Instrument can be used, the liability of the Payer, charges levied, and any other material information needed for an informed decision. Additionally, the parties may agree that the usual information requirements concerning individual Payment Transactions do not apply. Instead, the Payment Service Provider must provide or make available a reference to identify the Payment Transaction, the amount, and any charges payable. If the Payment Instrument is used anonymously or the Payment Service Provider is not technically able to provide this information, they must enable the Payer to verify the amount of Money stored. This flexibility allows for tailored agreements that suit the specific needs of low-value transactions. [#P:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21] [#P:8dd39e9b-0a4b-4ecc-a10e-960de38fea55]

question: In the context of Low-Value Payment Instruments, how does the requirement for information disclosure differ when governed by a Framework Contract, and what are the implications for Payment Service Providers regarding Payment Accounts and Stored Value?
gold_answer: When Low-Value Payment Instruments are governed by a Framework Contract, the Payment Service Provider is not obligated to disclose all general information as mandated by Section 19.2. Instead, they must provide the Payer with information about the main characteristics of the Payment Service, such as usage, liability, charges, and other essential details [#TGT:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21]. This requirement applies to instruments used in relation to both Payment Accounts and Stored Value, as specified under Rule 19.3.1 [#SRC:9098e83a-9451-476e-8f4a-60bedc364e14]. The parties may also agree to modify the information provided for individual Payment Transactions, allowing the Payment Service Provider to offer a reference for transaction identification and amounts, or total amounts for multiple transactions to the same Payee [#TGT:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21].
rag_answer: In the context of Low-Value Payment Instruments governed by a Framework Contract, the requirement for information disclosure is less comprehensive compared to standard Framework Contracts. Payment Service Providers are not obligated to disclose all general information as per Section 19.2 but must provide the Payer with key details about the Payment Service. This includes the usage of the Payment Instrument, the Payer's liability, charges levied, and any other material information necessary for an informed decision. Additionally, they must indicate where the general information concerning the Framework Contract is accessible [#P:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21]. Framework Contracts typically establish the terms for Payment Accounts or Stored Value issuance and redemption, detailing the rights and obligations of both parties [#P:f010077b-32aa-41ba-bbd9-6d043fae40ea]. For individual Payment Transactions, the parties may agree to limit the information provided, focusing on transaction identification, amounts, and charges, unless anonymity or technical limitations apply [#P:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21]. This streamlined approach allows Payment Service Providers to focus on essential information while maintaining compliance with the regulatory framework for Low-Value Payment Instruments.

question: What information must a Payment Service Provider give about Low-Value Payment Instruments when they are under a Framework Contract, and how does this relate to Payment Accounts and Stored Value?
gold_answer: For Low-Value Payment Instruments under a Framework Contract, the Payment Service Provider only needs to give the Payer key details about the service, like how to use the instrument, any charges, and liability issues [#TGT:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21]. This applies to instruments linked to both Payment Accounts and Stored Value [#SRC:9098e83a-9451-476e-8f4a-60bedc364e14]. The provider can also agree with the parties to simplify transaction information, offering a reference for identifying transactions and their amounts, or total amounts for similar transactions to the same Payee [#TGT:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21].
rag_answer: When a Payment Service Provider offers Low-Value Payment Instruments under a Framework Contract, they are required to provide specific information to the Payer. This includes details about the main characteristics of the Payment Service, such as how the Payment Instrument can be used, the liability of the Payer as per Rule 19.20.1, any charges levied, and other material information necessary for the Payer to make an informed decision. Additionally, the Payment Service Provider must indicate where the general information concerning the Framework Contract, as specified in Rule 19.2.1, is made available in an easily accessible manner [#P:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21]. Framework Contracts are typically used to establish Payment Accounts or the terms upon which Stored Value will be issued and redeemed, governing the operation of the payment service, including the rights and obligations of both parties [#P:f010077b-32aa-41ba-bbd9-6d043fae40ea]. This ensures that even for Low-Value Payment Instruments, the Payer is adequately informed and the contractual relationship is clearly defined.

question: When a Payment Order is initiated through a Payment Initiation Service Provider, what are the obligations of the Payment Service Provider regarding the provision of transaction details to the Payer and Payee, and how does Rule 19.5.3 affect these obligations?
gold_answer: When a Payment Order is initiated through a Payment Initiation Service Provider, the Payment Service Provider must obtain and disclose the reference for the Payment Transaction from the Payment Initiation Service Provider to fulfill its obligations under Rule 19.5.1, unless excluded by Rule 19.6.2 [#SRC:e26ca08e-5397-4da6-bc33-13c0bdc73939]. Additionally, subject to Rule 19.5.3, the Payment Service Provider must provide or make available to the Payer and, where applicable, to the Payee, immediately after the initiation of a Payment Order, several details: confirmation of the successful initiation, a reference for identifying the transaction, the transaction amount in the currency used, any applicable charges and their breakdown, the exchange rate used if applicable, the date of receipt of the Payment Order, and the Credit Value Date [#TGT:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622].
rag_answer: When a Payment Order is initiated through a Payment Initiation Service Provider, the Payment Service Provider has specific obligations to provide transaction details to both the Payer and, where applicable, the Payee. These obligations include providing confirmation of the successful initiation of the Payment Order, a reference to identify the Payment Transaction, the transaction amount, any applicable charges, the exchange rate used if applicable, the date of receipt of the Payment Order, and the Credit Value Date [#P:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622]. Rule 19.5.3 may introduce exceptions or additional conditions to these obligations, but the specific details of Rule 19.5.3 are not provided in the context, so its exact impact cannot be determined from the available information. It is important for the Payment Service Provider to adhere to these requirements immediately after the initiation of the Payment Order to ensure transparency and proper record-keeping for both the Payer and the Payee [#P:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622].

question: If a Payment Order starts with a Payment Initiation Service Provider, what must the Payment Service Provider do about sharing transaction details with the Payer and Payee?
gold_answer: When a Payment Order is initiated through a Payment Initiation Service Provider, the Payment Service Provider must get and share the transaction reference from the Payment Initiation Service Provider to meet its obligations, unless Rule 19.6.2 says otherwise [#SRC:e26ca08e-5397-4da6-bc33-13c0bdc73939]. Also, right after the Payment Order starts, the Payment Service Provider must give or make available to the Payer and Payee several details: confirmation of the order's initiation, a reference for identifying the transaction, the transaction amount, any charges and their breakdown, the exchange rate if used, the date the order was received, and the Credit Value Date [#TGT:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622].
rag_answer: When a Payment Order is initiated by a Payment Initiation Service Provider, the Payment Service Provider must ensure that specific transaction details are shared with both the Payer and, where applicable, the Payee. The Payment Service Provider is obligated to provide or make available the following information immediately after the initiation of the Payment Order: confirmation of the successful initiation of the Payment Order, a reference to identify the Payment Transaction, the amount of the Payment Transaction, any charges payable, the exchange rate used if applicable, the date the Payment Order was received, and the Credit Value Date [#P:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622]. Additionally, once the Payer has given consent to the Payment Initiation Service Provider to initiate the Payment Transaction, the Payer cannot revoke the Payment Order [#P:d4608c0e-c599-4e38-9326-d18988d235b4]. This ensures that both parties have the necessary information to track and verify the transaction, while also maintaining the integrity and finality of the Payment Order once consent is given.

question: Under what circumstances is a Payment Service Provider exempt from providing the general information required by Rule 19.5.1 for a single Payment Transaction, and what specific information must still be provided immediately after the initiation of a Payment Order?
gold_answer: A Payment Service Provider is exempt from providing the general information required by Rule 19.5.1 for a single Payment Transaction when the Payment Order is transmitted via a Payment Instrument issued under a Framework Contract, and the general information has already been provided or will be provided by another Payment Service Provider under Section 19.2 [#SRC:c337e2ea-0d58-45b9-970f-810639f88bf2]. However, immediately after the initiation of a Payment Order, the Payment Service Provider must still provide or make available to the Payer and, where applicable, the Payee, specific information including confirmation of the successful initiation, a reference for identifying the transaction, the transaction amount, any applicable charges and their breakdown, the exchange rate used if applicable, the date of receipt of the Payment Order, and the Credit Value Date [#TGT:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622].
rag_answer: A Payment Service Provider is exempt from providing the general information required by Rule 19.5.1 for a single Payment Transaction when the Payment Order is transmitted by way of a Payment Instrument issued under a Framework Contract, and the general information has already been provided or will be provided by another Payment Service Provider under Section 19.2 in respect of that Framework Contract [#P:c337e2ea-0d58-45b9-970f-810639f88bf2]. However, immediately after the initiation of a Payment Order, the Payment Service Provider must still provide or make available specific information to the Payer and, where applicable, to the Payee. This includes: (a) confirmation of the successful initiation of the Payment Order with the Payers Payment Service Provider; (b) a reference enabling the identification of the Payment Transaction, including the Payer and Payee, and any information transferred with the Payment Order; (c) the amount of the Payment Transaction in the currency used; (d) any charges payable and a breakdown of such charges; (e) the actual exchange rate used or a reference to it, and the amount after currency conversion; (f) the date the Payment Service Provider received the Payment Order; and (g) the Credit Value Date [#P:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622].

question: When does a Payment Service Provider not have to give general information for a single Payment Transaction, and what details must they still provide right after starting a Payment Order?
gold_answer: A Payment Service Provider does not have to give general information for a single Payment Transaction if the Payment Order is sent using a Payment Instrument under a Framework Contract, and another Payment Service Provider has given or will give that information [#SRC:c337e2ea-0d58-45b9-970f-810639f88bf2]. But right after starting a Payment Order, they must still provide details like confirmation of the start, a reference to identify the transaction, the transaction amount, any charges and their breakdown, the exchange rate if used, the date they got the Payment Order, and the Credit Value Date [#TGT:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622].
rag_answer:
A Payment Service Provider is not required to provide general information for a single Payment Transaction if the Payment Order is transmitted using a Payment Instrument issued under a Framework Contract, and the general information has already been provided or will be provided by another Payment Service Provider under the Framework Contract. However, the Payment Service Provider must still provide specific details immediately after initiating a Payment Order. These details include: 

- The information or unique identifier required for the Payment Order to be properly initiated or executed. [#P:8dd39e9b-0a4b-4ecc-a10e-960de38fea55]
- The maximum time in which the Payment Service will be executed. [#P:8dd39e9b-0a4b-4ecc-a10e-960de38fea55]
- The charges payable by the Payment Service User, including a breakdown of such charges if applicable. [#P:8dd39e9b-0a4b-4ecc-a10e-960de38fea55]
- Where applicable, the actual or Reference Exchange Rate to be applied to the Payment Transaction. [#P:8dd39e9b-0a4b-4ecc-a10e-960de38fea55]

This ensures that the Payment Service User is adequately informed about the specific transaction details, even if general information has been covered under a broader contract. [#P:c337e2ea-0d58-45b9-970f-810639f88bf2]

question: Under what circumstances is a Payment Service Provider exempt from providing the information required by Rule 19.5.3 for a Payment Order transmitted via a Payment Instrument issued under a Framework Contract?
gold_answer: A Payment Service Provider is exempt from providing the information required by Rule 19.5.3 when the Payment Order for an individual Payment Transaction is transmitted using a Payment Instrument issued under a Framework Contract. In such cases, the general information that would otherwise be required under Rule 19.5.1 does not need to be provided if it has already been or will be provided by another Payment Service Provider under Section 19.2 in relation to the Framework Contract [#TGT:c337e2ea-0d58-45b9-970f-810639f88bf2]. This exemption applies specifically to the information that would typically be provided immediately after the initiation of a Payment Order, including confirmation of initiation, transaction reference, transaction amount, charges, exchange rate details, and the Credit Value Date [#SRC:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622].
rag_answer: A Payment Service Provider is exempt from providing the information required by Rule 19.5.3 for a Payment Order transmitted via a Payment Instrument issued under a Framework Contract when the general information has already been provided or will be provided under Section 19.2 by another Payment Service Provider in respect of the Framework Contract. This exemption is specifically applicable to individual Payment Transactions where the Payment Order is transmitted by way of a Payment Instrument under such a contract. The key precondition for this exemption is that the necessary general information must have been or will be provided by another Payment Service Provider, thereby avoiding duplication of information. This ensures that the Payment Service User is not burdened with redundant information, streamlining the process and maintaining efficiency in communication between the parties involved. The exemption is designed to prevent unnecessary repetition of information that has already been communicated under the terms of the Framework Contract, thus simplifying the obligations of the Payment Service Provider in these specific circumstances. [#P:c337e2ea-0d58-45b9-970f-810639f88bf2] [#P:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b]

question: When does a Payment Service Provider not have to give the usual payment details after starting a Payment Order if it's done through a Payment Instrument under a Framework Contract?
gold_answer: A Payment Service Provider does not have to give the usual payment details after starting a Payment Order if the order is made through a Payment Instrument under a Framework Contract. This is because the general information required by Rule 19.5.1 may already be provided or will be provided by another Payment Service Provider under Section 19.2 for the Framework Contract [#TGT:c337e2ea-0d58-45b9-970f-810639f88bf2]. Normally, these details include confirmation of the order, transaction reference, amount, charges, exchange rate, and the Credit Value Date [#SRC:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622].
rag_answer: A Payment Service Provider is not required to provide the usual payment details for a Payment Order when it is initiated through a Payment Instrument under a Framework Contract if the general information has already been provided or will be provided by another Payment Service Provider in respect of that Framework Contract. This exception applies specifically to individual Payment Transactions transmitted by way of a Payment Instrument issued under such a contract. [#P:c337e2ea-0d58-45b9-970f-810639f88bf2] This means that if the necessary information has been covered under the Framework Contract, the Payment Service Provider handling the single transaction does not need to duplicate this information. [#P:c337e2ea-0d58-45b9-970f-810639f88bf2]

question: Under what conditions may a Payment Service Provider ensure that no other person has an interest in or right over Relevant Money in a Payment Account, and how must the account be designated and used according to the rules?
gold_answer: A Payment Service Provider must ensure that no person other than themselves has any interest in or right over the Relevant Money placed in a Payment Account, except as provided by the rules [#SRC:2274597c-26a4-41de-8299-26e8918278ca]. The Payment Account must be designated to clearly show that it is held for the purpose of safeguarding Relevant Money in accordance with Chapter 14 of the rules [#TGT:c8d42233-89b1-4569-99b3-e4eb5c831520]. Additionally, the account must be used exclusively for Payment Transactions and solely for holding Relevant Money [#TGT:c8d42233-89b1-4569-99b3-e4eb5c831520].
rag_answer: A Payment Service Provider must ensure that no other person has an interest in or right over Relevant Money in a Payment Account by adhering to specific conditions and designations. The account must be designated to clearly demonstrate that it is held for the purpose of safeguarding Relevant Money, in accordance with Chapter 14 of the rules, and it must be used exclusively for Payment Transactions and for holding Relevant Money [#P:c8d42233-89b1-4569-99b3-e4eb5c831520]. Additionally, no person other than the Payment Service Provider may have any interest in or right over the Relevant Money placed in a Payment Account, except as provided by the rules [#P:2274597c-26a4-41de-8299-26e8918278ca]. This ensures that the funds are protected and used solely for their intended purpose, maintaining the integrity and security of the Payment Account.

question: How should a Payment Service Provider make sure no one else has rights over Relevant Money in a Payment Account, and what should the account be used for?
gold_answer: A Payment Service Provider must ensure that no one else has any interest in or rights over the Relevant Money in a Payment Account, except as allowed by the rules [#SRC:2274597c-26a4-41de-8299-26e8918278ca]. The account must be clearly marked to show it is for safeguarding Relevant Money according to Chapter 14 [#TGT:c8d42233-89b1-4569-99b3-e4eb5c831520]. It should only be used for Payment Transactions and for holding Relevant Money [#TGT:c8d42233-89b1-4569-99b3-e4eb5c831520].
rag_answer: To ensure that no one else has rights over Relevant Money in a Payment Account, a Payment Service Provider must adhere to specific safeguarding and usage protocols. Firstly, the Payment Service Provider is required to safeguard Relevant Money by placing it in one or more Payment Accounts, ensuring that no other person has any interest in or right over this money, except as provided by the applicable rules [#P:2274597c-26a4-41de-8299-26e8918278ca]. The account should be used exclusively for holding Relevant Money, which is either retained in the Payment Account of the Payment Service User or held in a segregated manner for funding the redemption of Stored Value issued to the Payment Service User in connection with Payment Services [#P:28899ab4-d64c-4f97-9055-404ed26793c4]. Additionally, the Payment Service Provider is prohibited from accepting or distributing physical cash in the form of banknotes and coins, which underscores the importance of maintaining the integrity and security of the Relevant Money within the Payment Accounts [#P:4b86169a-20a4-4c56-91de-63c79ec98663]. By following these guidelines, the Payment Service Provider ensures compliance with the regulatory framework and protects the interests of the Payment Service Users.

question: What are the obligations of a Payment Service Provider regarding the segregation and designation of Relevant Money in a Payment Account?
gold_answer: A Payment Service Provider is required to maintain records of all Relevant Money that is segregated in compliance with Rule 19.7.2 [#SRC:d859b24c-b454-4cca-8232-b0e14a19c403]. Additionally, any Payment Account holding Relevant Money must be designated to clearly indicate its purpose of safeguarding such money in accordance with Chapter 14 of the Rules [#TGT:c8d42233-89b1-4569-99b3-e4eb5c831520]. The account must also be exclusively used for Payment Transactions and solely for holding Relevant Money [#TGT:c8d42233-89b1-4569-99b3-e4eb5c831520].
rag_answer: A Payment Service Provider (PSP) has specific obligations regarding the segregation and designation of Relevant Money in a Payment Account. Firstly, Relevant Money held by an Authorised Person conducting Payment Services must be treated as Client Money, ensuring its segregation for distribution purposes following a Pooling Event. This distribution should align with the balances in the Payment Accounts of Payment Service Users or be used for the redemption of Stored Value held by these users [#P:c023c656-8826-475f-ba8c-0eb4750d08d7]. Additionally, the PSP must maintain records of all Relevant Money that is segregated in accordance with the applicable rules [#P:d859b24c-b454-4cca-8232-b0e14a19c403]. Furthermore, when a Payment Service User transfers Money to their Payment Account, the PSP must ensure that the amount is made available and value dated immediately if the user is a Natural Person, or by the end of the next day in other cases [#P:dcafef60-fb3b-4a9d-8dc3-bdd94ee56a89]. These obligations ensure that the PSP manages and records Relevant Money appropriately, safeguarding the interests of Payment Service Users.

question: How should a Payment Service Provider handle Relevant Money in a Payment Account?
gold_answer: A Payment Service Provider must keep records of all Relevant Money that is segregated according to Rule 19.7.2 [#SRC:d859b24c-b454-4cca-8232-b0e14a19c403]. The Payment Account where this money is held must be labeled to show it is for safeguarding Relevant Money as per Chapter 14 [#TGT:c8d42233-89b1-4569-99b3-e4eb5c831520]. This account should only be used for Payment Transactions and for holding Relevant Money [#TGT:c8d42233-89b1-4569-99b3-e4eb5c831520].
rag_answer:
A Payment Service Provider must handle Relevant Money in a Payment Account by ensuring it is managed in accordance with specific regulatory requirements. Relevant Money is defined as any Money held or controlled by a Payment Service Provider on behalf of a Payment Service User, except for Money due and payable to the Authorised Person from the Payment Service User [#P:df059ad6-df2a-43c6-98df-2e0d5f7f21c5]. The handling of such money involves several key obligations:

- The Payment Service Provider must ensure that Money transferred to a Payment Account in the same currency is made available and value dated immediately if the user is a Natural Person, or no later than the end of the next day for other users [#P:dcafef60-fb3b-4a9d-8dc3-bdd94ee56a89].
- Money must be kept in a segregated manner if it is held for the purpose of funding the redemption of Stored Value issued to the Payment Service User [#P:28899ab4-d64c-4f97-9055-404ed26793c4].
- In cases of non-execution or defective execution of Payment Transactions initiated by the Payee, the Payment Service Provider must ensure the transaction amount is at the Payees disposal immediately after it is credited and value dated correctly [#P:82547cc1-b1d6-45dc-9fd7-bd6db089098b].

These procedures ensure the proper management and availability of Relevant Money, safeguarding the interests of Payment Service Users.

question: How must an Authorised Person ensure the protection of Client Money and Relevant Money when conducting Investment Business or delivering Payment Services, considering their responsibility for safeguarding Customer assets?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is required to arrange proper protection for Client Money and Relevant Money when they are responsible for these assets in the context of Investment Business or Payment Services [#SRC:c69593e4-12f2-4843-b91b-48b91755223f]. This obligation is grounded in the responsibility the Authorised Person has accepted for safeguarding Customer assets [#TGT:27d3191b-2bf8-4623-8e63-93445f4afc4f]. Proper safeguarding involves ensuring that these assets are held or controlled in a manner that aligns with the principles of protection as outlined in the regulatory framework. The Authorised Person must adhere to these principles to fulfill their duty of care towards the Client's assets and money.
rag_answer: To ensure the protection of Client Money and Relevant Money when conducting Investment Business or delivering Payment Services, an Authorised Person must arrange proper protection for these assets in accordance with their accepted responsibility. This involves safeguarding Client Money held or controlled on behalf of a Client during Investment Business activities and properly safeguarding Relevant Money during the delivery of Payment Services [#P:c69593e4-12f2-4843-b91b-48b91755223f]. The Authorised Person must ensure that they have control over or are responsible for the assets or money belonging to a Customer and must arrange for their protection as per the responsibility they have accepted [#P:27d3191b-2bf8-4623-8e63-93445f4afc4f]. It is important to note that Authorised Persons who only provide currency exchange and Money Remittance services, without offering Payment Services, are not considered to hold Client Assets in the form of Client Money or Relevant Money, and thus different safeguarding obligations may apply to them [#P:00ed250e-3550-41e1-9ba0-4271cafd1982]. This distinction is crucial for determining the specific safeguarding responsibilities of an Authorised Person.

question: What must an Authorised Person do to protect Client Money and Relevant Money when they are responsible for these in Investment Business or Payment Services?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must ensure the proper protection of Client Money and Relevant Money when they are responsible for these assets in the context of Investment Business or Payment Services [#SRC:c69593e4-12f2-4843-b91b-48b91755223f]. This responsibility is based on the obligation to safeguard Customer assets as per the accepted responsibility [#TGT:27d3191b-2bf8-4623-8e63-93445f4afc4f]. The Authorised Person must manage these assets in a way that complies with the regulatory requirements for protection, ensuring they are properly safeguarded.
rag_answer: To protect Client Money and Relevant Money when responsible for these in Investment Business or Payment Services, an Authorised Person must ensure proper safeguarding and segregation of these funds. Client Money, which includes any currency held on behalf of a Client, must be protected in accordance with the Client Money Rules, ensuring it is not commingled with the Authorised Person's own funds unless specific conditions are met, such as when dealing with a Professional Client who is a Market Counterparty and has acknowledged the lack of protection under these rules [#P:4028dd66-23c7-4a3b-b2a3-7ccc1a9338b9]. Relevant Money, held during the provision of Payment Services, must be treated similarly to Client Money, ensuring its segregation for distribution purposes following a Pooling Event, either according to Payment Account balances or for redeeming Stored Value [#P:c023c656-8826-475f-ba8c-0eb4750d08d7]. Additionally, Authorised Persons must arrange proper protection for these assets as part of their obligations under Principle 9 of the Principles for Authorised Persons, ensuring that Client Money and Relevant Money are safeguarded during the course of their business activities [#P:c69593e4-12f2-4843-b91b-48b91755223f]. This comprehensive approach ensures that client funds are adequately protected and managed in compliance with regulatory requirements.

question: What are the specific conditions an Authorised Person must satisfy to classify a Person as a Market Counterparty, considering both the qualification as a deemed Professional Client and the notification requirements?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person may classify a Person as a Market Counterparty if the Person qualifies as a deemed Professional Client in accordance with Rule 2.4.2 and the requirements in Rule 2.5(b) have been met [#SRC:fea099c3-b4b0-4ab5-8ad8-760375f23413]. Additionally, before finalizing this classification, the Authorised Person must ensure that the Person has received prior written notification of the classification as a Market Counterparty, either in relation to a specific Regulated Activity or Transaction, or for all such activities and transactions [#TGT:8ae4e16d-21d1-4180-a88b-83808f0b29b3]. The Person must also not have requested to be classified otherwise within the period specified in the notice [#TGT:8ae4e16d-21d1-4180-a88b-83808f0b29b3].
rag_answer: To classify a Person as a Market Counterparty, an Authorised Person must ensure that the individual qualifies as a "deemed" Professional Client and that specific notification requirements are met. Firstly, the Person must be a "deemed" Professional Client according to Rule 2.4.2, which is a prerequisite for classification as a Market Counterparty [#P:fea099c3-b4b0-4ab5-8ad8-760375f23413]. Secondly, the Authorised Person must provide the Person with a prior written notification of their classification as a Market Counterparty, either in relation to a specific Regulated Activity or Transaction, or for all such activities and transactions [#P:8ae4e16d-21d1-4180-a88b-83808f0b29b3]. The Person must not have requested to be classified otherwise within the period specified in the notice [#P:8ae4e16d-21d1-4180-a88b-83808f0b29b3]. Additionally, if the Market Counterparty is a fund, trust, or similar entity managed by a "deemed" Professional Client, the notification must be directed to the manager or holder of the assets [#P:a4c5356a-91f1-4689-854b-19489f0f1358]. These steps ensure that the classification process is transparent and that the Person is adequately informed and has the opportunity to contest the classification if desired.

question: What steps must an Authorised Person take to classify someone as a Market Counterparty, including both the rules about being a Professional Client and the need for written notice?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person may classify someone as a Market Counterparty if that person qualifies as a deemed Professional Client according to Rule 2.4.2 and meets the requirements in Rule 2.5(b) [#SRC:fea099c3-b4b0-4ab5-8ad8-760375f23413]. Before doing so, the Authorised Person must provide the person with a written notice about the classification, which can apply to a specific Regulated Activity or all such activities [#TGT:8ae4e16d-21d1-4180-a88b-83808f0b29b3]. The person must not have asked to be classified differently within the time given in the notice [#TGT:8ae4e16d-21d1-4180-a88b-83808f0b29b3].
rag_answer: To classify someone as a Market Counterparty, an Authorised Person must follow specific steps that ensure compliance with the regulatory framework. Firstly, the individual must qualify as a "deemed" Professional Client according to Rule 2.4.2 [#P:fea099c3-b4b0-4ab5-8ad8-760375f23413]. Additionally, the Authorised Person must meet the requirements outlined in Rule 2.5(b), which include providing the individual with a prior written notification of their classification as a Market Counterparty. This notification must specify whether the classification applies to a particular Regulated Activity or Transaction, or to all such activities and transactions [#P:8ae4e16d-21d1-4180-a88b-83808f0b29b3]. The individual must also be given a specified period within which they can request to be classified otherwise, and they must not have made such a request within that period [#P:8ae4e16d-21d1-4180-a88b-83808f0b29b3]. These steps ensure that the classification process is transparent and that the individual is aware of their rights and the implications of being classified as a Market Counterparty.

question: What are the record-keeping obligations of an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business concerning Client classification and agreements, and how do these relate to the procedures and notices required under the applicable Rules?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must include records of Client classification and Client agreements in their Resolution Pack as per Rules 2.7.1 and 3.7.1(d) [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. Additionally, they are required to maintain records of the procedures followed under these Rules, including documents evidencing the Client's classification [#TGT:9c409857-238c-4ad8-b88b-6e770b674f27]. Furthermore, any notice sent to the Client pursuant to these Rules, along with evidence of despatch, must also be recorded [#TGT:9c409857-238c-4ad8-b88b-6e770b674f27]. This comprehensive record-keeping ensures compliance with both the specific requirements for Client classification and agreements and the broader procedural and notification obligations.
rag_answer: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must adhere to specific record-keeping obligations concerning Client classification and agreements, as outlined in the applicable Rules. These obligations include maintaining records of the procedures followed for Client classification and any notices sent to Clients, ensuring evidence of dispatch is available [#P:9c409857-238c-4ad8-b88b-6e770b674f27]. Additionally, the Authorised Person must keep a record of each Client Agreement, including any amendments agreed upon with the Client, for a minimum of six years [#P:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2]. These records are crucial for demonstrating compliance with the Rules and must be included in the Resolution Pack, which serves as a comprehensive collection of documents necessary for the orderly resolution of the Authorised Person's business [#P:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. The Resolution Pack must also contain a master document that allows for the retrieval of each document within it, ensuring that all records related to Client classification and agreements are easily accessible [#P:9a2f70fe-ca63-4b72-a573-f428b37a1a24]. This structured approach to record-keeping supports regulatory compliance and facilitates efficient business operations.

question: What records must an Authorised Person keep about Client classification and agreements, and what other related documents are needed?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must keep records of Client classification and agreements as part of their Resolution Pack, according to specific rules [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. They also need to keep records of the procedures they followed, including documents showing how Clients are classified [#TGT:9c409857-238c-4ad8-b88b-6e770b674f27]. Additionally, any notices sent to Clients and proof of sending these notices must be recorded [#TGT:9c409857-238c-4ad8-b88b-6e770b674f27]. This ensures all necessary documentation is maintained for compliance.
rag_answer: An Authorised Person is required to maintain comprehensive records concerning Client classification and agreements, as well as related documents, to ensure compliance with regulatory obligations. Furthermore, when establishing a relationship with a Professional Client, the Authorised Person must inform them of their right to be classified as a Retail Client, the higher level of protection available to Retail Clients, the timeframe for electing this classification, and the Client's responsibility to inform the Authorised Person of any changes affecting their classification [#P:2fdcb781-5b8e-4284-8a81-496431b4ba82]. These obligations ensure that the Authorised Person maintains transparency and compliance with client classification and agreement requirements.

question: Under what conditions may a Customer and a Third Party Provider agree to modify the applicability of Rule 20.10.1 regarding requests for refunds, and how does this relate to the notification requirements for redress under Rule 20.10.2?
gold_answer: A Customer that is not a Natural Person may agree in writing with a Third Party Provider to modify the applicability of Rule 20.10.1 concerning requests for refunds [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. This agreement may include setting a different time period for addressing unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. However, the entitlement to redress under Rule 20.10.2 requires the Customer to notify the Third Party Provider without undue delay, and no later than twelve months after the transaction's execution, upon becoming aware of any such issues [#TGT:d299e513-87d9-47de-9c0f-1f15cca91cbb]. Therefore, any agreement to modify Rule 20.10.1 must consider the notification requirements of Rule 20.10.2 to ensure compliance and entitlement to redress.

This agreement allows flexibility in the notification period for redress, which typically requires the Customer to notify the Third Party Provider without undue delay and no later than twelve months after the transaction execution date [#P:d299e513-87d9-47de-9c0f-1f15cca91cbb]. However, if the Third Party Provider fails to provide or make available the required information concerning the Third Party Transaction as per Section 20.3, the Customer is entitled to redress regardless of whether they have notified the Third Party Provider within the agreed time period [#P:e0ee4cf0-d2ae-4d3b-8012-62c5be6043a7]. This exception ensures that the Customer's right to redress is protected even if the notification requirements are not met due to the Provider's failure to provide necessary information.

question: If a Customer and a Third Party Provider agree to change the rules about refund requests, what must the Customer do to still get redress for unauthorised transactions?
gold_answer: When a Customer that is not a Natural Person agrees with a Third Party Provider to change the rules about refund requests, they may set a different time period for handling unauthorised or incorrect transactions [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. However, to get redress, the Customer must notify the Third Party Provider without undue delay and no later than twelve months after the transaction date once they become aware of the issue [#TGT:d299e513-87d9-47de-9c0f-1f15cca91cbb]. This ensures the Customer's right to redress is maintained despite any changes to the refund request rules.

This notification is crucial to limit the Customer's liability and to initiate the refund process. The Customer is not liable for losses from unauthorised transactions if they have not acted fraudulently or with gross negligence, and if they have notified the Third Party Provider promptly after becoming aware of the issue [#P:5adbd32c-9d2c-4fd5-a1e8-060fba49ae90]. Additionally, the Third Party Provider is obligated to refund the Customer for the amount of the unauthorised transaction, less any amount already refunded to the Primary Financial Institution, provided the transaction was not authorised in accordance with the relevant rules [#P:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe]. It is important for the Customer to maintain records of all communications and notifications to ensure they can substantiate their claims if needed.

question: If a Customer is not a Natural Person, when can they change the rules about refunds with a Third Party Provider, and what must they do to get redress for a wrong transaction?

This ensures that any changes to the rules still allow for timely reporting and resolution of issues.

Additionally, the Governing Contract should include information about the Customer's right to receive revised terms and any alternative dispute resolution procedures available for redress [#P:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49].

question: Under what circumstances is a Customer entitled to redress for a Third Party Transaction when the Third Party Provider has not provided information as required by Section 20.3, despite the Customer's failure to notify within the time period specified in Rule 20.10.1?

The provision of such information is essential for the Customer to understand and manage their transactions effectively, and the lack of it constitutes a breach that allows for redress irrespective of the Customer's notification timing. question: Under what circumstances may a Customer who is not a Natural Person and a Third Party Provider agree to modify the applicability of Rule 20.10.1 concerning requests for refunds, and how does this interact with the entitlement to redress when the Third Party Provider fails to provide information as per Section 20.3?

question: If a business and a Third Party Provider agree to change the rules about refund requests, what happens if the Third Party Provider doesn't give the right information?
gold_answer: If a business (not a Natural Person) and a Third Party Provider agree to change the rules about refund requests, including the time period for unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions, they can do so in writing [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. However, if the Third Party Provider fails to provide the required information about the transaction as per Section 20.3, the business is still entitled to redress even if it hasn't notified the Third Party Provider within the agreed time period [#TGT:e0ee4cf0-d2ae-4d3b-8012-62c5be6043a7].

If the Third Party Provider does not provide the necessary information, the Customer may not be deemed to have accepted the changes, and the Customer retains the right to terminate the Governing Contract without charge before the changes take effect [#P:e589a1c4-5c02-41c8-adbd-e32cae4d5468]. Additionally, the Governing Contract must include details about the conditions for the payment of any refund to the Customer, ensuring transparency and clarity in the refund process [#P:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. question: Under what conditions is a Customer entitled to redress for an unauthorised or incorrectly executed Third Party Transaction, considering both the notification requirement and the information provision failure by the Third Party Provider?
gold_answer: A Customer is entitled to redress for an unauthorised or incorrectly executed Third Party Transaction if they notify their Third Party Provider without undue delay and no later than twelve months after becoming aware of the issue [#SRC:d299e513-87d9-47de-9c0f-1f15cca91cbb]. However, if the Third Party Provider has failed to provide or make available the necessary information concerning the transaction as required by Section 20.3, the Customer retains the right to redress even if they did not notify the provider within the specified twelve-month period [#TGT:e0ee4cf0-d2ae-4d3b-8012-62c5be6043a7].

[#P:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259] These conditions ensure that the Customer's right to redress is protected, provided they adhere to the notification timeline and the Third Party Provider fulfills its communication and refund obligations.

question: When can a Customer get redress for a wrong Third Party Transaction if they didn't tell the Third Party Provider on time?

[#P:bdcc781c-2074-4a3f-b425-2ec77aee973a] If the Third Party Provider fails in these obligations, the Customer's right to redress is preserved despite any delay in notification. question: Under what conditions may a Customer and a Third Party Provider agree to exclude certain rules, and how does this relate to the Third Party Provider's burden of proof in cases of disputed transactions?
gold_answer: A Customer that is not a Natural Person and a Third Party Provider may mutually agree in writing to exclude specific rules, such as those concerning charges for information, withdrawal of consent, and revocation of a Payment Order, among others [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. In cases where a Customer denies authorizing a Third Party Transaction or claims it was not correctly executed, the Third Party Provider must demonstrate that the transaction was authenticated, accurately recorded, and processed according to its procedures, and that no technical or service deficiencies occurred [#TGT:b0cfd1ae-ec85-4eb8-bc00-8e500e740a92]. The agreement to exclude certain rules does not negate the Third Party Provider's responsibility to prove the integrity of disputed transactions.
rag_answer: A Customer and a Third Party Provider may agree to exclude certain rules if such exclusions are explicitly agreed upon in writing between the parties. This agreement must be reflected in the Governing Contract, which outlines the terms and conditions of the relationship between the Customer and the Third Party Provider. The Governing Contract must include specific information about the Third Party Provider, the services offered, charges, communication methods, safeguards, and corrective measures, among other details [#P:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. In cases of disputed transactions, the Third Party Provider bears the burden of proof to demonstrate that the transaction was authenticated, accurately recorded, and not affected by a technical breakdown or other deficiency. This is particularly relevant when the Customer claims that a transaction was unauthorized. The Customer is not liable for unauthorized transactions unless they have acted fraudulently or with gross negligence, such as failing to protect their Personalised Security Credentials [#P:5adbd32c-9d2c-4fd5-a1e8-060fba49ae90]. Therefore, any exclusions agreed upon must not undermine the Customer's protections against unauthorized transactions, and the Third Party Provider must still ensure compliance with authentication and notification requirements.

question: When can a Customer and a Third Party Provider agree not to follow some rules, and what must the Provider prove if a transaction is disputed?
gold_answer: A Customer that is not a Natural Person can agree with a Third Party Provider in writing to not follow certain rules, like those about charges or consent withdrawal [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. If a transaction is disputed, the Third Party Provider must prove it was properly authorized, recorded, and processed, and that there were no technical issues or service problems [#TGT:b0cfd1ae-ec85-4eb8-bc00-8e500e740a92].

Additionally, they must demonstrate that the transaction was not affected by any technical breakdown or deficiency in the service provided by them or any third party they rely on for operational functions [#P:b0cfd1ae-ec85-4eb8-bc00-8e500e740a92]. This requirement ensures that the burden of proof lies with the Third Party Provider to validate the integrity and correctness of the transaction process, thereby protecting the Customer's interests in case of disputes.

question: Under what conditions must a Third Party Provider issue a refund for an unauthorised Third Party Transaction, and what are the specific refund obligations towards the Primary Financial Institution and the Customer?
gold_answer: A Third Party Provider is required to issue a refund for an unauthorised Third Party Transaction when it has been confirmed that the transaction was either unauthorised or incorrectly executed [#SRC:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259]. The refund must be provided as soon as practicable, and no later than the end of the day following this confirmation [#SRC:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259]. The Third Party Provider must refund the Primary Financial Institution for any amount it has already refunded to the Customer, and also refund the Customer for the amount of the unauthorised Payment Transaction, deducting any amount already refunded to the Primary Financial Institution [#TGT:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe].
rag_answer:
A Third Party Provider must issue a refund for an unauthorised Third Party Transaction when the transaction was not authorised in accordance with the relevant rules and leads to an unauthorised Payment Transaction. The specific refund obligations are as follows: 

- The Third Party Provider must refund the Primary Financial Institution for any amount that the institution may have already refunded to the Customer. [#P:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe]
- Additionally, the Third Party Provider must refund the Customer for the amount of the unauthorised Payment Transaction, deducting any amount already refunded to the Primary Financial Institution. [#P:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe]
- The refund must be provided as soon as practicable, and no later than the end of the day following the day on which the Third Party Provider has confirmed that the transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed. [#P:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259]

These obligations ensure that both the Primary Financial Institution and the Customer are promptly compensated for unauthorised transactions, maintaining trust in the financial system.

question: When does a Third Party Provider have to refund for an unauthorised transaction, and who gets the refund?
gold_answer: A Third Party Provider has to refund for an unauthorised transaction once it confirms that the transaction was not authorised or was executed incorrectly [#SRC:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259]. This refund should happen as soon as possible, but no later than the end of the next day after confirmation [#SRC:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259]. The refund must be given to the Primary Financial Institution for any amount it already refunded to the Customer, and to the Customer for the amount of the unauthorised transaction, minus any refund already given to the Primary Financial Institution [#TGT:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe].

The refund process involves two parties: the Primary Financial Institution and the Customer. The Third Party Provider is required to refund the Primary Financial Institution for any amount it may have already refunded to the Customer, and also refund the Customer for the amount of the unauthorised transaction, less any amount already refunded to the Primary Financial Institution [#P:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe]. However, an important exception exists: the requirement to provide a refund does not apply if the Third Party Provider has reasonable grounds to suspect fraudulent behavior by the Customer [#P:ddd7b7c2-8a0a-43d4-ab4e-f9dec2d2b012]. This structured approach ensures that both the Primary Financial Institution and the Customer are protected, while also safeguarding the Third Party Provider against potential fraud.

question: Under what conditions is a Third Party Provider exempt from the obligation to provide a refund for unauthorised Third Party Transactions, and what is the timeframe for providing a refund when no such exemption applies?
gold_answer: A Third Party Provider is exempt from the obligation to provide a refund for unauthorised Third Party Transactions if it has reasonable grounds to suspect fraudulent behaviour by the Customer [#SRC:ddd7b7c2-8a0a-43d4-ab4e-f9dec2d2b012]. When no such exemption applies, the Third Party Provider must provide a refund as soon as practicable, and no later than the end of the day following the day on which it has confirmed that the transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed [#TGT:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259].

question: When does a Third Party Provider not have to give a refund for an unauthorised transaction, and how quickly must they refund if they do have to?

This means that while some rules can be skipped, the Third Party Provider's liability for transaction errors remains.

If a mistake occurs, the Third Party Provider must prove that the transaction was not affected by a technical breakdown or other deficiencies in the service provided. [#P:b0cfd1ae-ec85-4eb8-bc00-8e500e740a92] Additionally, the Customer is not liable for losses from unauthorised transactions unless they acted fraudulently or with gross negligence regarding their security credentials. [#P:5adbd32c-9d2c-4fd5-a1e8-060fba49ae90] This means that even if certain rules are waived, the Third Party Provider retains the burden of proof and liability for unauthorised transactions unless specific exceptions apply. [#P:b0cfd1ae-ec85-4eb8-bc00-8e500e740a92]

question: What are the obligations of a Third Party Provider regarding the availability and accessibility of information related to dispute resolution services and the Governing Contract?
gold_answer: A Third Party Provider is required to ensure that information about dispute resolution services is made available to the Customer in a clear, comprehensive, and easily accessible form [#TGT:08650621-06b8-481f-8650-2c5ebdb06be0]. Additionally, the information specified under Rule 20.13.3 must be available on the website of the Third Party Provider, at its main office and branches, and included in the general terms and conditions of the Governing Contract [#SRC:055fc91a-22c6-4511-9508-b90212a4d414].
rag_answer: A Third Party Provider has specific obligations regarding the availability and accessibility of information related to dispute resolution services and the Governing Contract. Firstly, the Governing Contract must include comprehensive details about the Third Party Provider, the services offered, charges, communication methods, safeguards, and corrective measures, as well as terms for changes and termination of the contract, and redress options [#P:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. Additionally, the Third Party Provider is required to make available to the Customer the details of dispute resolution services that can handle disputes concerning the rights and obligations under the relevant chapter. This information must be presented in a clear, comprehensive, and easily accessible form [#P:08650621-06b8-481f-8650-2c5ebdb06be0]. These obligations ensure that Customers are well-informed about their rights and the procedures available to resolve any disputes, thereby promoting transparency and trust in the services provided.

question: How should a Third Party Provider share information about dispute resolution services and the Governing Contract with customers?
gold_answer: A Third Party Provider must provide details about dispute resolution services in a way that is clear, comprehensive, and easy for customers to access [#TGT:08650621-06b8-481f-8650-2c5ebdb06be0]. The information required by Rule 20.13.3 should also be available on the provider's website, at its main office and branches, and included in the general terms and conditions of the Governing Contract [#SRC:055fc91a-22c6-4511-9508-b90212a4d414].
rag_answer: A Third Party Provider must ensure that information about dispute resolution services and the Governing Contract is shared with customers in a clear and comprehensive manner. The Governing Contract, which outlines the terms of Third Party Services and the rights and obligations of both the provider and the customer, must be established before any services are provided [#P:36fdb41d-1bb9-40fc-8a87-e70906566ad1]. This contract must include specific information about the dispute resolution services available to customers, ensuring that these details are presented in a clear, comprehensive, and easily accessible form [#P:08650621-06b8-481f-8650-2c5ebdb06be0]. Additionally, the Governing Contract must contain clauses on the law applicable to the contract, the competent courts, and any alternative dispute resolution procedures available to the customer, along with methods for accessing them [#P:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. By adhering to these requirements, Third Party Providers can ensure that customers are well-informed about their rights and the mechanisms available for resolving disputes.

question: Under what circumstances may a Customer and a Third Party Provider agree to exclude the application of Rule 20.2.15 regarding charges for information, and how does this relate to the prohibition on charging for information under Section 20.2?
gold_answer: A Customer that is not a Natural Person and a Third Party Provider may mutually agree in writing to exclude the application of Rule 20.2.15, which pertains to charges for information [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. This agreement allows them to bypass the standard prohibition on charging for information that is required to be provided under Section 20.2 [#TGT:50664c7f-6f26-481a-8070-81ff2afddce3]. Such an agreement must be explicitly documented in writing between the parties involved.
rag_answer: A Customer and a Third Party Provider may agree to exclude the application of Rule 20.2.15 regarding charges for information when the Customer is not a Natural Person. In such cases, they can mutually decide in writing that Rule 20.2.15, which prohibits charging for information required to be provided under Section 20.2, does not apply. This agreement allows the Third Party Provider to charge for information that would otherwise be provided free of charge under the standard provisions of Section 20.2. [#P:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] However, it is important to note that this exclusion is only permissible when the Customer is not a Natural Person, meaning it applies to entities such as corporations or other legal entities rather than individual consumers. [#P:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] This flexibility in the contractual arrangement allows for tailored agreements that can accommodate the specific needs and circumstances of non-natural person Customers, potentially including more complex or frequent information requests that justify additional charges. [#P:409ed483-98f6-44e5-812d-17a33796c543]

question: When can a Customer and a Third Party Provider decide not to follow the rule about charges for information, and how does this connect to the rule that usually stops them from charging for information?
gold_answer: A Customer who is not a Natural Person and a Third Party Provider can agree in writing not to follow the rule about charges for information, specifically Rule 20.2.15 [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. This is related to the general rule that usually prevents charging for information required under Section 20.2 [#TGT:50664c7f-6f26-481a-8070-81ff2afddce3]. Their agreement must be documented in writing.

[#P:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]
